On October 1, 2010, the organization name for the Division Counsel (Large and Mid-Size Business) was changed to the Division Counsel (Large Business and International); CCDM 30.9.2.5 was revised accordingly.
The IRM reference in CCDM 30.9.2.7.3 was updated. Form numbers in CCDM 30.9.2.8 were
Minor editorial changes were made to meet IRM/CCDM requirements. Titles and hyperlinks were added to official forms and CCDM and IRM references throughout the section.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS CCDM 30.9.2 dated July 21, 2005 is superseded .

30.9.2.1 Published Guidance
for Specific Categories of Case Files 30.9.2
) This subsection provides guidelines for establishing and maintaining files related to regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, action on decisions, and other types of published guidance. (

) Open a regulation project only with approval from an Assistant or Associate Chief Counsel and, if it will appear on the Guidance Priority List, the Treasury Department. Depending on the procedures adopted by each Assistant or Associate office, front office or branch personnel may open a regulation on TECHMIS. (

) To open a regulation project, enter the TECHMIS “Add Case” screen and complete the required fields: category: PUBGUID, subcategory REG. In some circumstances, Counsel may decide to open the project using subcategory “PGP.” TECHMIS generates a project number (CASE ID) that begins with “REG” (or “PGP”, if applicable). Use only this CASE ID for all phases of the regulation process, from drafting the ANPRM/NPRM to publishing the final regulation. (
) IRC §

(e) requires the Service to issue a cross-referencing NPRM when issues temporary regulations. Open only one regulation project for temporary regulations with a cross-referencing NPRM. When the Service publishes the temporary regulations and cross referencing NPRM, update TECHMIS with status code
- TEMP/XREF Published. The CASE ID remains open until the Service publishes the NPRM as a final regulation or withdraws it and removes the temporary regulation. (

) Occasionally, Counsel and Treasury will decide to issue several final regula- tions with respect to one NPRM. The first final regulation project retains the original CASE ID. After publishing the first final regulation, close that CASE Open a new CASE ID for each subsequent final regulation project. In the TECHMIS remarks screen for each subsequent final regulation project, note the name and original CASE ID of the underlying NPRM and all related final regulations. Also enter this information in the remarks screen for the first final regulation. (
) After opening the regulation project on TECHMIS, the drafting attorney a legal file maintains the legal file, is responsible for its contents, and retains until the project is closed. (

) Punch holes at the top of the back cover of the legal file and all papers to be included in it. The first item in the file will be a copy of the TECHMIS control screen. Secure the papers with file fasteners. Label the file with the project and CASE ID. (
) The legal file contains all documents germane to the publication of the tion and, in accordance with Form
, Treasury Decision File Closing Information Sheet and Assembly Checklist , organized by subject files using Form

, Chief Counsel’s File. (Do not include duplicate material, any readily available printed matter [e.g., statutes and the associated legislative history, court decisions], or scraps, blank sheets, etc. that do not contain sub- stantive information). The attorney establishing the file and the reviewing attorney sign and date Form
) The subject files and materials to be included are: Chief Counsel Directives Manual
The subject files and materials to be included are:
(cid:
) Published Regulations and Notices— all initialed and certified copies of regulation (cid:
) Unmarked drafts — a clean copy of each draft and related buckslips and distribution memoranda (cid:
) Service and Treasury mark-ups — pertinent pages of mark-ups and buckslips and distribution memoranda (cid:
) Briefing Memos — internal memoranda prepared for briefings (cid:
) Service and Treasury Memos — transmittal and policy memos and comments (cid:
) Conference and Briefing Reports — summaries of conferences and sessions (cid:
) Public Comments— public comments, including summaries of these comments and documents related to the public hearing (cid:
) Administrative Memos — regulations subsystem form and regulations de- velopment checklist (if completed), Small Business Administration documents,
-point memo material, closing memo (if prepared), plain language summaries, and material prepared pursuant to the Paperwork Reduction Act and Small Business Regulatory Fairness Enforcement Act (
) Place handwritten notes and email communications in the appropriate matter file, in reverse chronological order. (
) Attach a copy of the Federal Register reprint to the cover of the legal file. (

) A regulations project is complete when the Service publishes an NPRM as a final regulation, withdraws a published NPRM without publishing final regula- tions, or decides not to publish a regulation. If the Service published a temporary regulation with a cross-referencing NPRM, the project is complete when the Service removes the temporary regulation and publishes the as a final regulation or withdraws the NPRM. (
) If the IRS publishes a final regulation, close the final regulation project on TECHMIS using status code
(closed - publication). If the IRS withdraws NPRM and does not publish final regulations, use status code

(closed - withdrawn). If the IRS decides not to publish a regulation, use status code (closed - non-publication). Refer to the TECHMIS handbook for additional status codes (closed - other, closed - transferred out, closed - opened in not described above. (
) All regulations projects close with classification code J (Regulation & Legisla- tion Projects). (
) When the legal file for a TD (final and temporary regulations) is complete, it with the TD number and submit it to the Docket, Records and User Fee Branch for storage. (
) The drafting attorney retains the NPRM file after the document is published reference for (and to be included in the legal file for) the final regulations. (
) After the Service withdraws a regulation or closes a project without it, assemble the legal file and send it to the Docket, Records and User Fee Branch in room
for storage. The attorney should prepare a closing memorandum to include in the legal file.
regulation (cid:

The drafting attorney retains the NPRM file after the document is published as reference for (and to be included in the legal file for) the final regulations.
for Specific Categories of Case Files
page (
) Revenue Rulings, Revenue Procedures, and other nonregulatory Published Guidance help Service personnel apply the tax laws correctly and uniformly and help taxpayers comply with the tax laws. (
) Before opening a guidance project, it must be approved by the Associate Counsel and, if it will appear on the Guidance Priority List, Treasury. (

) When approved, open the project on TECHMIS (category: Published Guidance, subcategory: RR, RP, or NOT as applicable) in accordance with TECHMIS Users Handbook. Depending on the procedures adopted by the Assistant or Associate Office, Branch or front office personnel may open the project. (

) Project titles must refer to the issue addressed, not a taxpayer name. If the project pertains to a prior publication, the project title must begin with that lication (i.e. Rev. Rul. XX-XX Revocation, not Revocation of XX-XX). (

) TECHMIS generates a project number (CASE ID) that begins with “NOT” for Notices and Announcements, “RP” for Revenue Procedures, “RR” for Rulings, and “PGP” for projects without an assigned format. Use only this project number for all phases of the publication process, from drafting publication. (
) The attorney drafting the published guidance project opens the legal file. The first item in the file will be a print-out of the TECHMIS control screen. (
) In general, the contents of the legal file for Revenue Rulings, Revenue dures, Announcements, and Notices will be the same. The legal file contains, in chronological order when possible: a. Form

, Case History b. A signed completed copy of the Background Information Note (BIN), taining the record of clearances, attachment list and all other pertinent information c. Background memoranda discussing the development of the project and comments from Treasury, Counsel, and Service officials and staff d. A copy of the first draft of the publication. e. A copy of each later draft (or part of the draft) that is significantly from prior drafts and/or contains information, such as substantive comments, that clarifies the meaning of the publication. File only the page(s) that contain the significant change and/or clarifying information. Put the date of the draft, title of the project, and project number on the page, and list the people who received a copy of the draft. f. A significant change is one that adopts a rule different from the one drafted and/or clarifies the meaning of the rule adopted. g. Briefing and conference memoranda h. Small Business Administration documents, plain language summaries, material prepared pursuant to the Paperwork Reduction Act and Small Business Regulatory Fairness Enforcement Act (if prepared) i. Bibliography of references analyzed when researching the project. Do include a copy of the research material unless it will facilitate future research. If included, highlight the critical text. j. Copies of material not available in the Chief Counsel library or on the Internet, including memorandum pertaining to other projects, studies, reports k. Written and oral comments, if any, from the public Chief Counsel Directives Manual
for Specific Categories of Case Files 30.9.2

, Case History b. A signed completed copy of the Background Information Note (BIN), con- taining the record of clearances, attachment list and all other pertinent information c. If included, highlight the critical text. j. Copies of material not available in the Chief Counsel library or on the Internet, including memorandum pertaining to other projects, studies, and reports k. Written and oral comments, if any, from the public

File l. “Comment” or “Suspend” memoranda from Treasury, the the Chief Counsel, or an Associate Chief Counsel, Division Counsel, member of their staff m. An original or copy of the approval memorandum n. Coordination memoranda from other Chief Counsel offices o. The Form
, Internal Revenue Bulletin Submission Record, and Form

, Memorandum for Bulletin Unit Coordinator, stamped by Bulletin Unit, that posts the publication number and the date of the and the IRB number in which it will appear p. A copy of the publication, as it appeared in the IRB q. Signed completed copy of Form

, Record of Bulletin Editorials r. A cross-reference sheet for each secondary Internal Revenue Code section listed in the “coding” at the top of the revenue ruling s. A copy or photocopy of any correction notice as it appeared in the IRB t. A closing memorandum (
) Do not include handwritten notes or email communications unless they address substantive matters addressed in the published guidance. (

) If a publication is newsworthy, the Service may pre-publish (“ early drop”) a document, prior to its publication in the Internal Revenue Bulletin, by news release, making it available to the tax services, and posting it to the Service web site. Put a copy of the memorandum authorizing the “early in the legal file. (
) When the Service publishes a revenue ruling or revenue procedure, close project on TECHMIS with status code
(closed - published). For items Service decides not to publish, use status code
(closed - Refer to the TECHMIS user guide for additional status codes (e.g., closed other, closed - transferred out, closed - opened in error) not described (

) Revenue Rulings and Revenue Procedures close with file retention code J Revenue Ruling or Procedure. For Notices, close with status code B if the is to be retained for reference, H if historical, and F if routine. (
) After issuing the published guidance, submit the legal file to the Docket, Records, and User Fee Branch for storage. (
) The legal file for AODs contains: (cid:
) A copy of the AOD (cid:
) A copy of the court opinion to which the AOD relates (cid:
) Conference and other memoranda discussing the basis on which the decision to issue an AOD was made and the contents of the AOD document (
) AOD assignments will be opened in the Associate office. (
) Closed AOD files will be forwarded to the Docket, Records and User Fee Branch for storage.

for Specific Categories of Case Files

) When the format of the published guidance project (e.g., Regulations, Ruling, Revenue Procedure, or Notice) has not been determined, a Guidance Guidance Project (PGP) on TECHMIS is opened, category: Published (PGP) Guidance, subcategory: PGP. TECHMIS will generate a CASE ID with “PGP.” (
) The drafting attorney opens the legal file. The first item in the file will be TECHMIS control screen. (

) PGPs are developed in the same manner as other published guidance projects. Accordingly, the contents of the PGP legal file will include the material as the legal file for other published guidance. (

) When an Associate office determines the kind of published guidance to open a new project on TECHMIS using the subcategory to which the be converted. Continue using the existing PGP legal file, conforming it to appropriate specifications. (
) Close the PGP on TECHMIS, with status code
(closed - other) and fication code F (routine). (
) This subsection discusses establishing and maintaining files for pricing agreements, change in accounting methods, change in Case period, and private letter rulings. (
) The team leader maintains and closes the official APA case file, insuring the file contains the following material: Pricing (cid:
) The taxpayer’s request for APA and related documents (APA) (cid:
) The case plan (cid:
) A file memorandum, or file note, for every meeting or significant call (cid:
) Copies of all outgoing correspondence, such as questions or requests sent to the taxpayer (cid:

) Copies of documents (including email messages) that perform the of a conference memo, memorialize a decision, or transmit comments draft document (cid:

) Close CAM and CAP cases on TECHMIS (TECHMIS — CAM or CAP screen) with the appropriate closing status code. (

) After closing the CAM or CAP on TECHMIS submit the files for advanced consent cases to the Docket, Records, and User Fee Unit for storage. The retention schedule requires the Service to retain “automatics” for three After two years, the files may be retired to the Federal Records Center. (

) Taxpayers address requests for a PLR to the Docket, Records, and User Branch (CC:PA:LPD:DRU). The DRU picks up the mail, screens the for subject matter jurisdiction, opens the case on TECHMIS, and creates a legal file. The CASE-ID will begin with the prefix PLR. (
) The DRU opens the PLR legal file. It contains: (cid:
) The taxpayer’s submission, including the taxpayer’s request for a letter ruling, checklists submitted pursuant to Rev. Proc.

(or quent annual revenue procedure) and other applicable Service Penalties of Perjury Statement, Power of Attorney, and documents and other material supporting the taxpayer’s request for private letter ruling (cid:
) A copy of the TECHMIS general detail opening case screen (“ control sheet”)

After closing the CAM or CAP on TECHMIS submit the files for advanced consent cases to the Docket, Records, and User Fee Unit for storage. The retention schedule requires the Service to retain “automatics” for three years. After two years, the files may be retired to the Federal Records Center.

) At the request of the Commissioner, the Office of Chief Counsel determines whether to grant taxpayers’ requests for relief pursuant to IRC §
The opening and closing procedures for requests for
relief and the contents the legal file are the same as those outlined for private letter rulings. The file will also include: (cid:
) If the taxpayer submitted its request to the Commissioner’s office and not CC:PA:LPD:DRU, the memorandum from the Commissioner forwarding case to Counsel (cid:
) Copies of the taxpayer’s tax returns for all applicable years (cid:

) A copy of Counsel’s disposition memorandum notifying the Commissioner whether Counsel issued a private letter ruling granting or denying the tax- payer’s request for relief or the taxpayer withdrew its request for IRC §
relief. If the taxpayer withdrew its request for IRC §
relief, Counsel will not issue an adverse private letter ruling. (

) Sometimes taxpayers request closing agreements in addition to or in lieu of private letter rulings. These requests are addressed similarly and processed the DRU similarly to PLR requests. The CASE ID will begin with the prefix CLAG. The file created by the DRU will be similar to a PLR file. The drafting attorney, however, creates a CLAG Special File. The Special File is a temporary file in a manila folder containing all papers relating to the closing agreement. Mark the outside of the folder SPECIAL FILE and label it with the taxpayer name, CASE ID, and office symbol of the branch handling the case. The Special File contains the following: (cid:
) The file created in CC:PA:LPD:DRU (cid:
) All subsequent correspondence from the taxpayer (cid:
) Reports from revenue agents and/or office reports (cid:
) Official file copies of the closing agreement and, if issued, the private letter ruling (cid:
) The original and copies of the transmittal letter and memorandum to the taxpayer and appropriate Director (cid:
) Three copies of private letter ruling, if prepared, for each closing in file (cid:
) Closing agreements, executed in triplicate, with necessary documentary evidence (cid:
) Manifold copies, excluding the yellow copy (cid:
) For a “Mass Closing Agreement” or other agreement that a taxpayer sentative signs for a taxpayer, the power of attorney authorizing the representative to sign the original closing agreement (cid:
) Material to be used by the Operating Division examining the returns (cid:
) Transmittal memorandum to the Associate Chief Counsel (cid:
) If the closing agreement is subject to public disclosure as an integral part a private letter ruling, a redacted copy of both the closing agreement and the private letter ruling (
) After the appropriate officials sign the closing agreement and return it to the branch, photocopy the original closing agreement, prepare deleted copies in accordance with CCDM

, Special File. The Associate Chief Counsel office retains the original and a copy of the closing agreement and a copy of the related private letter ruling, if any, and transmittal memorandum to the Operating Division. If applicable, associate the Special File with the legal file for the private letter ruling. Close the CLAG on TECHMIS using the appli- cable closing status code (see appendix for closing status codes). Use Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

) Files should be sent to the Docket, Records and User Fee Branch when the case is closed. (

) The legal file is the official file of the Office of Chief Counsel in a Tax Court case. It is created in the National Office upon the service of a new Tax Court petition upon the Chief Counsel. The Docket, Records and User Fee Branch, upon entering the case in the TL CATS system, makes up the legal file by filing the petition and other papers served on the Chief Counsel in the file jacket. One TL CATS generated label is permanently attached to the face of the legal file and the other placed inside the legal file for the field office’s use. The DRU then mails the legal file containing the petition and its attachments the appropriate Field office. (

) Because the DRU’s allocation of cases between SB/SE/LB&I/TEGE can only be a rough approximation of the responsible Division, there may be initial assignment of cases, and it may be desirable to transfer primary to a different Division from that originally assigned. Until the case is formally transferred, the Field group originally assigned the case remains responsible for assuring that all necessary actions (e.g., answering the case) are taken in timely fashion. Because of concern that administrative files may be lost or misplaced if the case is reassigned before retrieval of the administrative file, the Division originally assigned a case should generally answer the case prior to transfer to any group in a different geographic location. At the request or written consent of the transferring organization, however, the case may be transferred prior to answer. The case file and TL CATS/TECHMIS will be ap- propriately annotated to reflect the Division and local office responsibilities respect to the case. (
) In addition to containing the formally approved official documents, the legal should reflect the current status of the case at all times.

In addition to containing the formally approved official documents, the legal file should reflect the current status of the case at all times.
File (

) Copies of all incoming inter-office memoranda for a case should be date- stamped when received and placed in the legal file. Copies of the final signed original version of all outgoing memoranda should be placed in the legal file. Where Counsel has reviewed a proposed statutory notice of deficiency, of any memorandum concerning pre-issuance review should be placed in the legal file for the docketed proceeding. (

) The attorney should prepare memoranda for the file to record all principal action in the case, which is not otherwise reflected therein by formal documents. This will enable the supervisor or another attorney to whom the case may be assigned, to ascertain from the file the current status of the as well as what action has been taken therein. Memoranda for the file should be prepared of principal action taken by the attorney in telephone or informal conversations having a material bearing on the processing or disposition of case. Conference memoranda should also be prepared, when applicable, in the predocketed consideration of a case, and such memoranda should be inserted in the legal file when the case becomes docketed. Each for the file should be dated and signed by the attorney preparing it. (

) Copies of all incoming correspondence (including printouts of email should be date-stamped when received and placed in the legal file. Copies of the final signed original version of all outgoing correspondence should be placed in the legal file. (

) The copy of the Tax Court petition (and all exhibits thereto) served upon re- spondent should be retained in the legal file. Similarly, copies of any amended petition or amendments to a petition should be retained in the legal file. (
) A complete copy of the statutory notice of deficiency upon which a docketed case is based should be placed in the legal file. (

) There should be in the legal file a record of all principal action taken by the attorney towards the disposition of the case by trial or settlement. These matters oftentimes are important in the consideration of the case by the National Office for tax litigation advice, review of briefs or actions on decision. Information contained in the office file or the administrative file does not fulfill this requirement. (

) The initialed copy of all papers filed with the Tax Court, together with a copy such papers bearing the stamped impression when a particular paper was sent, was lodged, or was filed, etc., with the court, the served copy, the final signed original of all outgoing correspondence, the originals of all incoming respondence, and any other pertinent papers must be filed in the legal file strictly in chronological order, with the most recent on top. (
) The original of served subpoenas should be included in the legal or miscella- neous law file. A reviewer’s approval should also appear in the file by of the initialed copy or other means. (

) The first documents in the legal file for a case settled by Appeals should be Appeals Case Memorandum and supporting statement. Included with such material should be a complete copy of any Audit Statement, computations, account transcripts for the relevant taxable periods. (
) For each case settled by Counsel, a complete copy of the final signed original Counsel Settlement Memorandum should be kept in the legal file. The file Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
Z
For each case settled by Counsel, a complete copy of the final signed original Counsel Settlement Memorandum should be kept in the legal file. The file
Categories of Case Files
page should also contain a copy of the stipulated decision entered by the Court a copy of any pertinent settlement computations. (
) For cases that are not settled, the file should contain the documents that dispose of the case, e.g., the order dismissing the case or the opinion and decision document. (
) When a Tax Court case is appealed, whether by the taxpayer or the govern- ment, responsibility for the case is transferred to the Associate office with primary subject matter jurisdiction. (

) The legal file is transmitted to the Department of Justice for its use in the appellate litigation. Before transmitting the file to Justice, attorneys should care to retain copies of essential case documents in a duplicate legal file. (

) When the case is resolved on appeal, Justice will return the legal file to the Associate office. Unless the case is remanded to the Tax Court, the office will close the case and send the file to the Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch for processing. (
) If the case is remanded, the legal file will be returned to the responsible counsel office. (

) Court of Federal Claims refund cases are forwarded to the Legal Division in the national office. The Division assigns the case to a field office, creates a legal file and requests the administrative file from the Service. The legal file is then forwarded to the assigned field office. (

) Upon receipt of the summons and complaint in a district court or Court of Federal Claims case by Field counsel, a designated reviewer (an attorney paralegal) should read the complaint to determine if the case is in the Field counsel office and if the matter should be controlled as a tax litigation function case or as a general litigation or general legal services matter. (

) Case Categories. Every case jacketed in a Field office must be designated report purposes as set forth in paragraph, below. For the most part, the type case to be designated on the file jacket is easily ascertained. At times cases and matters are assigned to the general litigation activity that do not clearly within the specific categories of cases. (

) Documents placed in the legal file should be securely fastened to the file. Bulky briefs or trial or deposition transcripts may be stored in a manila file envelope, provided the envelope is clearly marked to indicate that it is a the legal file. The legal file should accompany any letter sent to an office for review. (

) The legal file should contain a copy of all of the filings and Court documents and trial or deposition transcripts furnished by the Department of Justice; a copy of all correspondence sent to or received from the Department of or any other agency or Service office; a copy of memoranda to the file prepared by the attorney; and a copy of all transcripts of account. The file should also contain technical advice memoranda, legal advice, or letter showing any prior Office of Chief Counsel consideration of the case. the legal file will contain only one copy of each document.
Guidelines for Specific Categories of Case Files 30.9.2

Upon receipt of the summons and complaint in a district court or Court of Federal Claims case by Field counsel, a designated reviewer (an attorney or paralegal) should read the complaint to determine if the case is in the correct Field counsel office and if the matter should be controlled as a tax litigation function case or as a general litigation or general legal services matter.

Case Categories. Every case jacketed in a Field office must be designated for report purposes as set forth in paragraph, below. For the most part, the type of case to be designated on the file jacket is easily ascertained. At times cases and matters are assigned to the general litigation activity that do not clearly fall within the specific categories of cases.

) Copies of all incoming inter-office memoranda for a case should be date- stamped when received and placed in the legal file. Copies of the final original version of all outgoing memoranda should be placed in the legal file. Where Counsel has reviewed a proposed statutory notice of deficiency, of any memorandum concerning pre-issuance review should be placed in legal file for the docketed proceeding. (

) The attorney should prepare memoranda for the file to record all principal action in the case, which is not otherwise reflected therein by formal documents. This will enable the supervisor or another attorney to whom the case may be assigned, to ascertain from the file the current status of the as well as what action has been taken therein. Memoranda for the file be prepared of principal action taken by the attorney in telephone or conversations having a material bearing on the processing or disposition of case. Conference memoranda should also be prepared, when applicable, in the pre-docketed consideration of a case, and such memoranda should be inserted in the legal file when the case becomes docketed. Each for the file should be dated and signed by the attorney preparing it. (

) Copies of all incoming correspondence (including printouts of email should be date-stamped when received and placed in the legal file. Copies the final signed original version of all outgoing correspondence should be placed in the legal file. (
) When a refund case is ready for closing, a closing memorandum is returning the administrative files to the Service. (
) In any case in which a refund has been made, a copy of the recomputation used to determine the amount refundable and a copy of the Notice of ment memorandum should be in the legal file. (

) An important and crucial prerequisite to the closing of a refund case in money is repaid is the preparation and transmittal to the service center of a payment memorandum known as a notice of adjustment. (
) In a refund case, include a signed copy of the original Settlement Letter that was prepared by the attorney and sent to the Department of Justice. (

) When a District Court or Court of Federal Claims case is appealed, whether the taxpayer or the government, responsibility for the case is transferred to Court Associate office with primary subject matter jurisdiction. Cases (
) The legal file is transferred from the Field counsel office to the Associate for appeal monitoring. (

) When the case is resolved on appeal, Justice will return the legal file to the Associate office. Unless the case is remanded, the Associate office will the case and send the file to the Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch processing. (
) If the case is remanded, the legal file will be returned to the responsible counsel office. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
Z
In a refund case, include a signed copy of the original Settlement Letter was prepared by the attorney and sent to the Department of Justice.
for Specific Categories of Case Files 30.9.2

changes in the area of CT file creation and maintenance, as well as how when CT cases are to be closed. This section establishes general for file opening, maintenance and closing of all types of CT cases. Unless otherwise stated, these procedures apply to all CT cases, whether worked in field offices or in the headquarters office. To the extent specific procedures not covered herein, they will be provided separately by the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax) and/or by the Area Counsel. (

) The original and copies of all incoming correspondence, forms, transmittal memoranda, and/or reports must be stamped upon receipt to show the date and office in which received. For incoming Field Counsel assignments, the Area Counsel must also be immediately notified upon receipt of the new as- signment. The number of exhibits and/or attachments received with the agent’s report (SAR) or other incoming correspondence are to be checked make certain that they correspond to number and identification as listed in SAR or other incoming correspondence, and that all specified exhibits and tachments have been received. (

) CASEMIS databases (hereinafter CASE) should be searched to determine whether a case(s) related to the incoming target/assignment has been previ- ously handled. All relevant CASE screen(s) should be printed and with the incoming assignment. (
) All new CT workload matters on which two or more hours will be spent are be opened on CASE and a separate CASE number should be assigned to each proposed target in a Form
, Request for Grand Jury Investigation, SAR. In the case of forfeitures, a separate CASE Number will be assigned each Form
, Seized Property Report, received from CI. (
) One case jacket (file folder) will be prepared, taking into account the guidelines: a. For administrative and grand jury cases, the file will be in the name of key target, proposed in the Form

or SAR, regardless of the of targets. For grand jury cases, the case jacket should also be “GRAND JURY.” b. For forfeitures, the file will be in the name of the primary property item seized, with a cross reference to the property owner c. For search warrants, the file will be in the name of the proposed target d. For summonses, the file will be in the name of the proposed target e. For all other categories of case files, see the Division Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax) and/or Area Counsel for instruction (
) The following information should be recorded on the face of the case jacket: a. The name and address found in the Form

or SAR for the key recommended, and in the case of forfeitures, the name of the owner of property and the property items seized b. All other names or aliases used by the target or business entity c. Names of related cases (actual and/or proposed targets) Chief Counsel Directives Manual
key target, proposed in the Form

or SAR, regardless of the of targets. a. The name and address found in the Form

or SAR for the key target recommended, and in the case of forfeitures, the name of the owner of the property and the property items seized b. All other names or aliases used by the target or business entity c. Names of related cases (actual and/or proposed targets)

File d. Cases involving numbered proposed targets with tax violations relating corporations which are not numbered targets should be captioned: Doe John Involving ABC Corporation e. The CI POD in which the case arises (

) With certain exceptions which require written submissions (e.g. search warrants), requests for legal assistance from CI may be written or oral, and, generally, responses should be in like form. It is beneficial to memorialize legal assistance rendered since subsequent criminal cases containing a ecution recommendation may be based in part or whole on the prereferral legal assistance provided. Files on oral legal assistance are at the the CT Manager. (
) An appropriate case jacket should be opened for any written legal advice. (

) Initially, the CT file will contain one copy of the incoming correspondence or documentation giving rise to the assignment. While the assignment is copies of all case related correspondence/documentation, as well as each work product (e.g., conference memorandum, supplemental investigation requests, criminal evaluation memorandum, forfeiture memorandum of law) also be enclosed in the file. Additionally, all relevant CASE screen(s) should printed and placed in the case jacket. This material should be fastened in file folder in reverse chronological order. (

) No notations or marks are to be made on the originals of documents from taxpayers or their representatives other than the necessary stamp to record the date and place of receipt. No notations, marks, or corrections are be made on originals of the exhibits, or on papers or tax returns received administrative officials in connection with criminal tax cases and matters. (

) The criminal tax file should always remain in the assigned CT office, except the case of transfers. When the case is transferred, the complete file will be copied, unless directed otherwise by the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax) and/or Area Counsel; the original documentation to the newly assigned office; and the copies retained by the transferring These same procedures will apply for transmittals to Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax) for review and evaluation. (

) With CI’s and CT’s increased use of electronic transmission of CT attorneys should look to the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax) and Area Counsel for additional advice relative to the and retention of electronic files. (

) Administrative files should only be received in rare instances. In these situa- tions, action should be taken immediately and the administrative file returned. To the extent administrative files are transmitted to CT attorneys, proper precaution regarding original tax returns should be maintained. (
) Security measures should be observed at all times to avoid jeopardizing a case through loss of files or unauthorized disclosure of the contents thereof. Tax (

) Generally, CT case files and CI records in CT possession are classified as High Security items. The protection for these items involves storage in containers (i.e., locked file cabinets) or in areas protected by a secure Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
Z
Security measures should be observed at all times to avoid jeopardizing a case through loss of files or unauthorized disclosure of the contents thereof.
Specific Categories of Case Files
page (
) The security guidelines offered by IRM

, Minimum Protection (MPS), deal with the protection of sensitive tax data and grand jury from purposeful or inadvertent disclosure, as well as protection of Service personnel and equipment. You should be aware of the guidelines the Service utilizes in this regard, and comply with them. (

) When additional security precautions are deemed advisable, the correspon- dence should be placed in double-sealed envelopes, clearly marked OPEN ADDRESSEE ONLY on the inner envelope. This requirement is inclusive of copy distribution. To assure that all correspondence comes unopened to the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax) the mailing should be stamped NOT TO BE OPENED IN THE MAIL ROOM. (

) When transmitting by mail, original documents which may be used as in trial (e.g., original returns, signed confessions, books and records, etc.), istered mail with confirmation of delivery requested or a comparable method delivery should be used. A private service may be an appropriate method of delivery if the sender can be notified that all of the material sent reached its destination and that there is a method of tracing material which is lost en route. Should confirmation of notification of delivery not be received by the office transmitting such files or documents within a reasonable period of time, inquiry should be made to trace the material. (
) Except where noted below, cases opened after July

should be on CASE immediately upon completing the requested action. Exceptions are those cases in which Counsel is the referral authority, primarily summons en- forcement cases and certain forfeiture cases. (

) Closing a criminal tax case encompasses closing the case on CASE, taking closing action relative to any file that was created and sending copies of specified documents to the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel Tax) and Area Counsel for review. (
) Closing a criminal tax case on CASE does not mean that the referral of the criminal case is “terminated” within the meaning of IRC §
)(B). a. “The responsibility for closing [a] criminal investigation rests with the referring authority.” Prior to July
, Counsel was the referral authority for (a) requests for grand jury of Title
and/or Title
-related offenses and (b) recommendations to prosecute Title
and/or Title

- related offenses investigated administratively. b. For those cases in which Counsel is the referral authority, unless other arrangements are made with CI and the Department of Justice, when Counsel learns that such a case has been resolved within the meaning IRC §
)(B), Counsel should take action to obtain the needed writing” case closing information from Justice. (

) CASE operators must be timely advised of the need to close a criminal tax case on CASE by being provided with a copy of any closing document. If is no formal closing document, the CT attorney should take care to advise CASE operator of the date the action on the case was completed so that the case can be closed as of that date. (
) The date the advice is rendered and/or the action document transmitted is date the case will be put in
status on the CASE system. In the majority cases, immediately thereafter, the case should be closed, i.e., put in

, Records Control Schedule for the Chief Counsel. jury files should be reviewed before any file is shipped to make sure that grand jury material is properly handled. (
) CI should be contacted periodically to determine if referred grand jury gations are still active. If the matter is no longer active, Counsel should the matter. The “in writing” requirement of IRC §

)(B) need not the any particular form and can be as simple as a concurrence line to a CI tinuance memorandum, provided the document clearly sets forth that the referral to DOJ is terminated and an appropriate Justice official (e.g., the United States Attorney or his or her delegate) signs on the concurrence (

) For grand jury requests, if a prosecution recommendation results, the grand jury request case should be closed on CASE as of the date the special report is received and the grand jury evaluation case is opened. Counsel remains the referral authority for the matter. The closing of the grand jury request case on CASE is merely for Counsel record keeping purposes and does not “terminate” the referral. (
) Cases in which Counsel recommended prosecution, forfeiture or summons forcement as the referral authority should be closed within five (

) workdays receipt of sufficient information from which it can be reasonably determined that the criminal aspects have been concluded. Grand jury evaluation cases where Counsel was the referral authority for the underlying grand jury should also follow this rule. (

) If a case is prosecuted, the automatic closing procedures set forth below be used. If a recommendation for prosecution is not authorized by DOJ, or discontinued by Justice prior to indictment after authorization, the case can closed upon receipt of the declination letter from Justice of a final tion made that the declination will not be protested or the case resubmitted with additional evidence. (

) In the following categories of cases, the Tax Division has agreed to the immediate closing and release for civil disposition of the criminal case by Service without Tax Division authorization: a. ) Where a case is being closed pursuant to the above automatic closing dures, notification to the Tax Division is made by letter containing the and commitment order and/or as much of the following information as a. The date of the indictment or information b. A listing of the counts by year and charge c. The judgment entered on each count d. The date of that judgment and verdict or plea on which it was based e. The exact sentence imposed on each count f. Date of sentence g. Whether an appeal was filed and the results, including an opinion h. Date any petition for writ of certiorari was denied i. Whether the case should be forwarded for supervision of collection (i.e., any fines were imposed, any restitution ordered or costs imposed by court) j. Any other applicable information (

) Two sets of case numbers are used by the Office of Associate Chief (General Legal Services). a. The first set is composed of three parts: the GLS prefix, a six digit generated by TECHMIS, an automated case tracking system, and a digit suffix denoting the last two digits of the calendar year. b. The second set is a GLS file number generated by TECHMIS for local GLS use. It is composed of a “GLS” prefix, followed by a two character geographic office designation, followed by an ordering number of digits, and concluded with a two-digit suffix denoting the last two digits the calendar year (each character set separated by a hyphen). ) If the principal work product of the case is oral advice, work on a task force, preparation for meetings, memoranda to the file must be placed in the folder indicating the advice given, recommendations made, and similar information. Attorneys and paralegals are responsible for ensuring that all material documents are in case files, in proper order, and securely fastened with clips. All bound documents, i.e., transcripts, separate MSPB Agency Response should be referred to in the case file and put in a secondary file next to the case file in the docket room or storage area. GLS cases are closed promptly when action on the case, i.e., final dum of advice or other responsive action is completed and no further significant work product or verbal advice is anticipated for the case.
